discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Set the AAVE D3M DC to 0 (Zero)

content.content: Motivation This Signal Request is inspired by a conversation on the MakerDAO Discord Channel, and community member @makercaesar who ask what is the current state of the AAVE Direct Deposit DAI Module. We believe it is important to ask what are the Current Risks of continuing to be exposed to another platform?  (100M at Risk for 1.4M in Revenue)  Overview The current market environment is too volatile and it is separating the stronger lending protocols everywhere, centralized or not, from those who have lower risk standards. Unfortunately AAVE is loaded with risk right now with a large exposure to stETH. AAVE also has a large surface area due to cross-collateralization (unlike Maker) where the locked collateral like ETH and WBTC in the protocol can be taken out by other borrowers. It also operates on multiple chains which means that is carries exposure to centralized bridge failure risk on all those chains as well. It’s a risky environment in general to extend a 100M Debt Ceiling when the dominant theme is redemption. The AAVE-DAI pool currently has enough reserves right now for MakerDAO to withdraw. If the DAI reserves become empty, any periodic DAI repayments from other borrowers will be snatched quickly by bots and a protocol like MakerDAO will be locked-in for a long time. Similar to how Central Banks increase or decrease Money Supply, the D3M was originally meant to supply liquidity on a short term basis,  and MakerDAO can risk locking its liquidity up for a long time. It’s a small percentage of total MakerDAO TVL, but the amount is large enough to cause issues to the surplus buffer.  PROS  Risk Profile is now higher (100M at Risk) and these new factors should be discussed. The Stability Fee rate in Maker and AAVE are already at parity which means we do not need this D3M to operate right now, so it can be turned off without causing any issues. MKR token owners, community members, and Delegates should gather data and analysis from folks who are monitoring various data points on this thread so that MakerDAO can make an informed choice.   CONS  Decrease in DAI deposits via the AAVE D3M Decrease in D3M will hamper 1,000,000++ DAI income to Maker( Source )     SET The AAVE D3M DC Temporarily to 0 (Zero)  Yes No Abstain     0 voters     Poll Closes on 20/06/2022 at 17:00 UTC
content.GPT-summary: The author of the proposal is explaining the motivation behind the signal request to set the AAVE D3M DC to 0. They argue that the current market environment is too volatile and that AAVE is loaded with risk, making it important to ask what the current risks are of continuing to be exposed to another platform. The proposal outlines the pros and cons of setting the AAVE D3M DC to 0 and invites the community to gather data and analysis to make an informed choice. The post also includes a poll for community members to vote on the proposal.

None

content.content: Hey Frank, Thanks for posting this. Can you clarify whether this SR is asking to explore setting the Aave D3M DC to 0, or whether it will directly set the DC to 0 if passed (assuming it passes on-chain and in an exec), even if only temporarily?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Sorry, the latter(changed Title)–assuming the consensus is to set the DC to Zero, even if only temporarily.

flipflopflapdelegate:  It’s a small percentage of total MakerDAO TVL, but the amount is large enough to cause issues to the surplus buffer.   Then its worth exploring. We don’t want buffer issues, especially in the current market.

content.content: Even if there’s staked ETH issue, AAVE system overall is very unlikely to be undercollaterized considering it’s backed by various collaterals. I don’t see a reason to hardcode to cut off a profitable operation

content.content: I don’t think there is need to set the D3M to 0. D3M is fascinating tool to distribute DAI liquidity across the DeFi and especially for the Aave Protocol market. stETH is trading with slight around 5% discount/de-peg from ETH due to its nature as a derivative asset, however the de-peg would actually need to be quite substantial up to 20% to see risk of bad debt to increase (where another measure of Safety Module would be the way to clear the debt). See more Staked ETH and AAVE Risk (June 11th Update) - Liquidation - Aave

3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Aave-DAI pool would not feel an impact from the pause because the rates are already low. MakerDAO loses about ~100k DAI in revenue for pausing D3M for a month. Please correct me if I’m wrong but the main Aave Ethereum market has not been migrated to your new V3 codebase, which means governance does not have the ability to set debt ceilings for any collateral types? Whether it is under your control or not, Aave governance has let stETH become the largest collateral type on the platform. The recommendations from your risk team to handle this issue seemed to have spooked some of your own users already.  In a protocol like Aave where bad debt effects all pools/users I’ve been surprised and extremely disappointed to watch this play out. As systemic risk builds you continue to loosen stEth’s risk parameters. It seems Aave has managed to recreate the system of socialized bailouts - increasing risk for all users to try to protect a few whales. Because of this around a week ago I closed all my positions from Aave for the time being. I am a hard NACK on changing anything at this point - I already think you’ve made multiple missteps and this is just another bad decision trying to play puppeteer.  link to comment: Staked ETH and AAVE Risk (June 11th Update) - #6 by bred - Liquidation - Aave Key point here is “for the time being”. At minimum, this should go on-chain to let MKR holders decide since this is a risk parameter that their MKR backstops.

content.content: EthWarrior:  D3M is fascinating tool to distribute DAI liquidity across the DeFi and especially for the Aave Protocol market.   For sure. We call All agree on that. I believe the bigger question for myself as a Maker Delegate and other Maker Delegates, along with MKR token owners should be how much longer do we continue to live on a prayer that this Market reverses and Mariano Conti doesn’t have to publicly suggest to Celcius to switch from WBTC-A to WBTC-B gradually (for lower LR 145% → 130%). One would think a “professional outfit” should always have an exit playbook; therefore I believe MKR token should always prioritize Maker risk management over their own book.
Really great to see a delegate showing some leadership. I voted yes.
Does this have to be binary, DC could be halved as a compromise.

Good point—In hindsight I should have also created a Poll with your suggestion, and @vamsi suggestion of  going with a fixed term (maybe for 1 month ) and then a re-evaluation (~100k over a month) hopefully by then market conditions will stabilize. Might need to do another Poll, or perhaps someone here will create a compelling one with those suggested risk mitigation options, and others.

None of the topics listed match

content.content: By the same token, if we think there is real acute risk the DC should be 0. Regardless, under current AAVE rates and the volatile environment the risk reward calculus appears unfavorable: (50k revenue/mo vs potential 50mm loss) compared to (100k revenue/mo vs. potential 100mm loss). We are talking about a possibly existential risk to Maker for nominal revenue. We just cleared a considerable amount of liquidations as income this month. This possibly existential risk is in addition to the reputational risk to MakerDAO from which recovery would be unlikely. Look at the current MKR price, it is already irrational based on solid past performance of Maker. What would happen with some bad PR and sentiment? The best thing we have going for us right now is our value as a solid, conservative, and reliable protocol. It would behoove us to take steps to protect this market position. From the MKR holder perspective the risk/reward brings concerns. It is very easy to turn the D3M back on if conditions make it desirable ( a simple signal request), it is near impossible to clean up a mess or put back any damage once done. Let’s consider being conservative now, as the markets appear to warrant it?

content.content: MakerDAO: Long-term Growth Strategy for the Future of DeFi   The first step to unlocking this growth is to fill up the surplus buffer, or cushion, to robust levels. Far from being a pool of capital functional to finance investments that couldn’t be covered by ongoing profitability, a surplus buffer is a capital cushion to protect the protocol from ‘unknown unknowns’, or risks that although yet unobservable do indeed exist. Maker has already learned through its young life how over-collateralisation cannot be the answer to every shock.   Outside of views on what the line parameter should be, this SR illustrates the need the Maker system has for a more robust capital stack, as outlined in this post: MakerDAO: Long-term Growth Strategy for the Future of DeFi

content.content: This feels like an overreaction brought on by the current market activity and the fates of Terra and Celcius. I think it’s worth considering just quite how much needs to go wrong in order for Maker to be negatively affected here.  stETH price needs to break down to the point where liquidations start to happen. Liquidations need to happen at a rate that results in Aave taking bad debt. Aave needs to be unable to cover all of that bad debt out of its surplus. Aave needs to be unable to cover all of that bad debt using their Safety Module. The market needs to lose confidence in Aave to prompt a bank run. Aave needs to be unable to convince some VC/Whales to provide a bailout. MakerDAO needs to write-off the remaining bad debt from Aave ← FIRST POINT MAKER PROTOCOL TAKES LOSSES The MakerDAO surplus buffer needs to not be able to cover the bad debt. MakerDAO needs to be unable to recover sufficient DAI using the flop mechanism to balance the bad debt. ← FIRST POINT MKR HOLDERS TAKE REALIZED LOSSES The market needs to lose confidence in MakerDAO to prompt a bank run. MakerDAO needs to be unable to convince some VC/Whales to provide a bailout. ← POINT MAKER COLLAPSES  Secondly, it’s worth considering how much value is actually at risk in Aave due to the stETH thing, and how much bad debt can be absorbed by the existing layers of defence in both Aave and Maker.  There are 450M dollars worth of ETH borrowed. Some percentage of that ETH is not collateralized by staked ETH. stETH is not going to significantly and durably break from ETH price absent an issue with Lido. Say Aave ends up with bad debt equal to 33% of 450M - that’s 150M (and is frankly a large overestimate) Aave had 40M of non-AAVE reserves in March (presumably more by now) Aave have ~100M of AAVE reserves. The Aave Safety Module has 120M of AAVE reserves. (note only 30% of this can be used for one event) The Aave-Balancer Safety Module has 86M of liquidity tokens as a reserve. (note only 30% of this can be used for one event) The Aave market cap is 835M. MakerDAO has 82M of surplus buffer. Maker has market cap of 760M.  Numbers are rounded judiciously, but you get the point. Layers of defence are how we reduce the risk of problems affecting us significantly to negligible values. We do this in Maker as well (over-collateralization, liquidation penalty, surplus buffer, MKR market cap, etc etc). (View my own, not GovAlpha’s)

content.content: After today’s proposal by Gauntlet our team believes Maker should disable D3M for the time being. The proposed 90% liquidation threshold is a risky move, even though there’s some rationale behind the proposal. The reason we believe this is risky is because out of 200m DAI borrowed on Aave Ethereum v2, 100m DAI is being borrowed by Celsius and collateralized mostly by stETH. Although the 90% liquidation threshold can have some benefits against stETH/ETH depeg, it presents a high risk for users borrowing stablecoins collateralized by stETH, especially when knowing Celsius is under stress right now.  1600×732 177 KB  This Aave governance proposal hasn’t passed yet and there is a possibility that it won’t since part of the community objected to the proposal. That said, we believe that Maker should proceed with caution in this case, especially now when already the low revenue (1.40% APY) from this exposure doesn’t offset the potential tail risks. Depending on the developments in coming weeks, @Risk-Core-Unit will present their view on the situation at the next MOMC meeting in about 2 weeks (and potentially suggesting to enable D3M back on). We therefore propose to disable Aave D3M (set DC to 0 and bar to 79%) in the executive vote tomorrow.

content.content: ^^^^^ For visibility: @Recognized-Delegates @Derek @cmooney @brianmcmichael @prose11 @GovAlpha-Core-Unit

Real question here @Primoz as i somewhat agree with @LongForWisdom  that setting the DC to 0 is an over-reaction.   While I tend to be more conservative than most on more issues I have long advocated Maker taking on some risk when this is balanced against the SB eating losses. Why DC 0 here vs. going to something like 50-100M? You talk about disabling D3M but you don’t give a real risk analysis of how much Maker could lose with various DCs and event situations?   This is one thing I find lacking from Risk generally is a graduated approach to risk reports.    Like given a DC level and a list of risk situations what is the loss hazard. Now it might be better to put these decisions in a larger global context (i.e maybe Maker is better suited to focusing on bonds and RWA). and or whether this decision has implications for other D3Ms (Compound). My point is can we get from Risk CU some better grain and quality on these decisions so governance can make a real risk, reward judgement here vs. a binary we suggest this, yes/no. Thank you in advance.

Also no comment on whether given this situation Maker should still put on top burner of work Compound D3M. content.content: Liquidation Threshold, similar parameter to CR in Maker.  This is specific to the current situation in Aave v2 Main market and a governance proposal to further lower collateralization req when using stETH as collateral. D3M is a general thing, Compound for example does not have stETH specific risk currently.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Oh.   I am used to seeing this as a ratio of collateral to borrow (so 90% would be more like 110% LR)   Thank you. I am trying to understand the real issues here.   Is this concern about stETH/ETH ratio or just an ETH price in general that the stETH/ETH price may move too fast for the buffer between stETH/ETH to be able to liquidate and contain losses? I guess given the market at this time prudence would say just get out of the way here, especially if DAI borrowing rates are not attractive.  Personally I would think if the markets thought there was an issue DAI rates would climb pretty dramatically on AAVE in response to this hazard (people would be pulling DAI like Maker Risk is suggesting).

content.content: I am voting “Yes” because I believe that the D3M poses an untenable amount of risk to MKR holders for a different reason. Aave has a complete & total reliance on Chainlink’s accuracy and integrity for the survival of its lending markets. Aave accepts Chainlink data with no sanity check or circuit breaker of any sort. If Chainlink sends bad price data for any asset, or if Chainlink’s 4-of-9 multisig is otherwise compromised, all lending positions on Aave would immediately find themselves incorrectly liquidated. MKR holders should not be saddled with this kind of trust requirement. Aave’s total trust in Chainlink’s multisig-secured price feeds flies in the face of the principles of decentralization that MakerDAO stands for. Aave D3M should be put on hold at least until Aave takes necessary steps to remove this very dangerous single-point-of-failure.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I voted Yes, in the current market conditions, any variable against is a risk that cannot be ignored.
